discussion.content: preboot execution environment (PXE)   Technology that enables a PC to boot without any local storage by retrieving an OS from a server over a network.

questions.question_text: Which of the following must be enabled to configure 20 new machines to be booted over a network?

discussion.content: The answers are A & E. WiFi does not take as much battery as a Cellular Network.

Doesn't make sense that A is a correct answer. Active background applications have been proven not to negatively effect battery life or processing power. It is a myth that both experts, and Apple themselves, had spoken against multiple times.

INCREASING the time to dim would mean it takes longer for the screen to dim, so can't be B, I actually chose that thinking the screen would dim faster, but you would be decreasing the time if you wanted that.

Your phone still uses the cellular antena even if wi fi antena is on and you're connected to wi fi right? So having both on, wouldn't that drain more battery? It's not like cellular antena shuts off when you're connected to wi fi....

Mobile data 4g always consume more battery than Wi-fi. reason being 4g base station tower is always far distance while comparing the Wi-fi access point. So mobile needs to send signal with high power to 4g base station when mobile data is on where as with the wifi it needs to send with the less power.

comments.content: But you're using both antenas... it's not one or the other, so wi fi becomes an extra power drainer, I would suggest turning off wi fi antena and use cellular signal only. So A and F? The only reason you would use wi fi is to save your data, not battery, no?

discussion.content: Having Wi-Fi turned on drains your battery if you're not using it, but if you're on a wireless network, it's much more power-efficient to use Wi-Fi than to use cellular data, so switch to Wi-Fi instead of your mobile network when you can to save your phone's battery

A is a given, leaving B and E as possible best second answers. typically increasing the time to dim the screen automatically is assuming there are long gaps between when the employee would keep the phone idle and benefit off this feature. Connecting to the WIFI network automatically only benefits the user if assuming that employee spends a significant amount of time on their phone and not actually doing work. B and E more often depend on the employees usage and habits more than any other factor. But the giveaway is in the office. Dimming the screen does not pertain to the office, but the WIFI is directly used in the office. Answers A and E and this is a horrible question as either one can make a strong case and dont make you a better tech.

comments.content: Thanks, almost got me with that one
Read it again, it's a red herring, if it said reduce the time then you would be correct

discussion.content: I Believe the Answer is A and B. Certainly, Wifi plays a factor but it does not have a significant impact on battery performances when compared to the screen backlight and active applications. The backlight of a mobile phone requires constant battery use.

I think A&E are correct :
Having Wi-Fi on drains your battery if you're not using it, but if you're on a wireless network, it's much more power-efficient to use Wi-Fi than to use cellular data, so switch to Wi-Fi instead of 4G when you can to save your phone's battery life.

comments.content: These kind of questions are on the exam!!!

discussion.content: I know this is a troll answer but turn down the brightness, but surely they can give us better answers than this , maybe questions that will actually be relevant in our field
searching for WIFI to connect to uses lots of juice A&E is correct
i also choose A&B funny the answer is A&E

comments.content: I'm thinking it's A and F. WiFi chows more battery life than Mobile Data
Increasing the time to dim will make it so the screen is on longer.
Doesen't B. Increase the time to dim the screen automatically drain the battery faster?

Logically using all scenarios, using A&E is correct. B is incorrect because that would only help specific users that seldomly use their phone. If an employee is active enough to not trigger screen dimming, then changing that setting will be pointless. A&E works for all scenarios. The phone constantly searching for 4/5g takes up a lot of battery. Try using your cellphone without going on the wifi in a hospital. Ill bet it drains extremely fast trying to search for signal. (only place i could think of that always has poor wireless signal)

discussion.content: I say A & B. Why would automatically connecting to the WIFI help with preserving the battery.

choices.A: Close applications when tasks are completed.
choices.D: Set the smartphone display to maximum brightness.
choices.C: Increase the frequency for syncing corporate email.
choices.F: Disable 802.11ac and use mobile data exclusively.
choices.E: Connect to the office WiFi network automatically.
choices.B: Increase the time to dim the screen automatically.

questions.question_text:
An employee contacts the help desk because the battery in a company-provided smartphone lasts only a short period of time when the worker is in the office.
Which of the following would MOST likely reduce this symptom? (Select TWO).

A technician has just finished installing a secondary OS on a workstation. After rebooting the computer, the technician receives the following error: No OS found. The technician confirms the boot.ini file is correct.
Which of the following is MOST likely causing this error?

discussion.content: An active partition is a partition on a hard drive set as the bootable partition that contains the operating system. If a wrong partition is set active, naturally operating system cannot be found.

Selected Answer: C
Marking a partition as active on a basic disk means that the computer will use the 
loader (an operating system tool) on that partition to start the operating system. The primary partition can be made bootable, by marking partition as active. The extended partition can not be marked as active partition. Do not mark a partition as active if it doesn't contain the loader for an operating system. Doing so will make your computer unbootable.

choices.C: An incompatible partition is marked as active
choices.D: An unsupported version of Windows is installed
choices.A: The computer has GRUB Legacy installed
choices.B: Windows Startup services are not running

choices.D: This account is designed for users who require temporary access to a computer and do not need to store user-specific settings. Users of this account have very limited permissions.
choices.A: This account is designed to have the ability to set permissions for other users on the system. Users of this account have the capability to perform any operation or task on the system.
choices.C: This account is designed for users who require specific administrator rights or permissions. Users of this account are restricted from installing software but can change time zones.
choices.B: This account is designed to provide basic permissions for completing common daily tasks. Users of this account are restricted from performing things like installing new software.

comments.content:
MY bad fam
A. Admin
B. Standard User - Recommended for day-to-day ops, which has much more limited capabilities than the Admin account, and is able to run installed programs. Ordinary Users can also change the time zone, and install a local printer. 
C. Power User
D. Guest - Has only limited rights/capabilities, no privacy, cannot save changes made to the desktop environment.

discussion.content:
A. is Admin
B. Guest
C. Power User
D. User

questions.question_text: Which of the following BEST describes the Guest account on a Windows system?

A SOHO user calls a technician and wants to secure a home network. The SOHO user needs to have protection from physical connections and ensure that employees cannot access applications or personal emails. Which of the following would the technician MOST likely configure on the new network device to accommodate this SOHO user's request? (Select TWO).

discussion.content: Physical connection probably means wired. So d makes sense
There has to be a physical barrier so others cannot have access to physical connections so physical security must be selected.
I'd pick A, D. I don't know what is implied by "physical security", is it port security or what? If it was I'd pick that over Mac filtering.
